docs.lead_paragraph: A state investigation into the death of a 4-year-old Manhattan girl several days after she had a routine tonsillectomy has faulted both her health maintenance organization and the hospital where she had her surgery. Deziree Wade, who was enrolled in the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, had her operation at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan on the morning of March 17. She was released the same day. Four days later, she bled to death at home, with blood spurting from an artery where her right tonsil had been.

headline.main: State Faults H.M.O. and Hospital in Death

docs.lead_paragraph: Three major manufacturers of silicone breast implants proposed a new settlement yesterday that would both significantly reduce previous offers to thousands of women and also make it harder for them to collect awards. Under the new plan, the companies' individual contributions may rise sharply. In the original plan, the liability of all implant manufacturers, including Dow Corning, which is not part of the new plan, was limited to $4.25 billion over 30 years, but under the new agreement, the three manufacturers will pay every participating woman who qualifies. If all women who qualify choose to participate in it, an outcome that is unlikely, the present-day value of the deal could be $3 billion for the three manufacturers involved in the new proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Democrats today rebelled against Republican efforts to cut projected spending on health care for the elderly, walking out of a committee session on Medicare that they called a charade. Senate Democrats, taking a different tack, offered an alternative that would reduce spending less severely than the Republican plan. The Democrats' action was further evidence of a breakdown in relations between the two political parties in the House, especially on the issue of Medicare. Today's developments also showed that Democrats in the two chambers seemed to favor somewhat different strategies.

headline.main: Democrats Storm Out of Medicare Session

docs.lead_paragraph: Funny things happened around this city last year when a half dozen health care plans battled to enroll a quarter of a million poor people. The plans that signed up the most people could get tens of millions of dollars under TennCare, a new state health system. So, some promised new members free life insurance and secured credit cards. One offered holiday turkeys to members who enrolled friends. Homeless people recall being besieged by sales representatives and signing up with any number of them.

headline.main: A Free-for-All in Swapping Medicaid for Managed Care

docs.lead_paragraph: In a day of emotional ups and downs, negotiators for several major producers of silicone breast implants and for thousands of women who say the devices have caused illness inched yesterday toward an 11th-hour plan that could help resolve about half of those claims. In a bid to meet a deadline and avert a rush on courthouses nationwide, the negotiators talked into the evening at the Hugo Black Federal Courthouse in Birmingham, Ala. The mood among the participants had soared earlier in the day, with participants expressing confidence that an agreement was imminent. But the spirits grew more somber during the evening and the talks ended about 11 P.M.

docs.lead_paragraph: In 18 years as a Senator from New Jersey, Bill Bradley said, he has never seen such a passionate response to any issue. What has prompted thousands of letters, postcards and phone calls is Mr. Bradley's bill to force health insurers to pay for at least 48 hours of hospital care for newborn babies and their mothers. It is co-sponsored by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Republican of Kansas.

headline.main: Bradley Predicts Passage of Bill to Insure 48-Hour Maternity Stays

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare reform might well be the most important legislation the Republicans will pass this year. The G.O.P. promised to protect health care for the elderly and, if possible, apply some of the savings toward deficit reduction. The bill the Senate Finance Committee approved last week turns those priorities upside down. Above all else, it cuts $270 billion out of the program, a figure driven by the need to balance the budget in seven years. The mammoth cuts jeopardize the quality of care provided to the elderly. The bill's worst defects are remediable, but only if Senate Republicans are willing to drop their ideological blinders long enough to adopt some sensible safeguards by floor amendment.

docs.lead_paragraph: For four years, construction executives watched with dismay as George A. Tomasso again and again underbid them on state projects, transforming a start-up company into the largest road and bridge builder in Connecticut. While competitors grumbled privately that something was amiss, state officials brushed aside complaints and said the law was the law: contracts must be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder.

headline.main: Builder's Fall Halts Projects In Connecticut

docs.lead_paragraph: The political discourse in the capital these days is dominated by charges and countercharges about Medicare. So are television commercials at certain times of the day, as Republicans and Democrats, home on a 10-day Congressional recess, try to sell their views to the voters. Republicans maintain that their sole purpose is to protect Medicare from bankruptcy. They say Democrats are burying their heads in the sand. Democrats hold that Republicans want to gut the program, which provides health care for 37 million elderly and disabled Americans, to offset a tax cut for the wealthy.

headline.main: Washington Memo;The Medicare Brawl: Finger-Pointing, Hyperbole and the Facts Behind Them
